domains.name: Gross Motor Development
domains.description: Gross motor skills involve large muscle movements like walking, running, jumping, and climbing. These skills are essential for physical independence, participation in sports and play, and overall health. Strong gross motor development supports balance, coordination, and body awareness, which are foundational for more complex physical activities and daily tasks.

tier1.question: Does your child pull themselves up to a standing position using furniture?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Pulling to stand is a foundational milestone for walking.

tier1.question: Does your child move sideways while holding onto furniture?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Cruising shows readiness for independent walking.

tier1.question: Can your child stand alone for a few seconds?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Standing independently reflects growing strength and balance.

tier1.question: Does your child take steps while holding your hands or a walker?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Supported walking precedes independent walking.

tier1.question: Does your child crawl or move efficiently to reach objects?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Independent mobility supports exploration and learning.

tier1.question: Can your child sit steadily without support?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Stable sitting supports play and fine motor skills.

tier2.question: Does your child attempt to climb onto furniture or stairs?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Climbing shows developing strength and spatial awareness.

tier2.question: Can your child squat to pick up a toy and return to standing?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Squatting requires good balance and leg strength.

tier2.question: Can your child walk a few steps without support or holding on?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Independent walking is a major gross motor milestone at this age.

tier2.question: Does your child change positions easily, like from lying to sitting or sitting to standing?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Smooth transitions show developing motor planning and coordination.

tier2.question: Can your child bend over to pick something up without falling over?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Bending and recovering shows advanced balance control.

tier1.question: Can your child pick up small objects using thumb and finger?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Pincer grasp is a key fine-motor milestone.

tier1.question: Does your child pass toys from one hand to the other?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Hand transfer supports coordinated movement.

tier1.question: Does your child bang two toys together during play?
tier1.whyWeAsk: This shows purposeful hand use and curiosity.

tier1.question: Does your child intentionally drop or place objects?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Controlled release supports play and learning.

tier1.question: Does your child use their index finger to poke or explore objects?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Isolated finger use supports later pointing and communication.

tier2.question: Can your child stack two or more blocks?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Stacking requires precision and planning.

tier2.question: Does your child try to turn pages in a book?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Page turning shows developing finger control and interest in books.

tier2.question: Can your child put objects into a container and take them out?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Container play shows understanding of spatial relationships and hand control.

tier2.question: Does your child hold a crayon or marker and make marks on paper?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Early mark-making is a foundation for drawing and writing skills.

tier2.question: Can your child use both hands together for activities like holding a toy steady while manipulating it?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Coordinated use of both hands supports complex tasks.

domains.name: Speech & Language
domains.description: Speech and language development encompasses both the ability to produce clear sounds (speech) and to understand and use words meaningfully (language). Strong communication skills are fundamental for expressing needs, building relationships, learning in school, and participating fully in social situations. Delays in this area can impact all aspects of development.

tier1.question: Does your child usually respond when their name is called?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Name response is a high-signal early communication skill.

tier1.question: Does your child use gestures like pointing, waving, or reaching to communicate?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Gestures are precursors to spoken language.

tier1.question: Does your child use simple sounds or a few words (e.g., "mama", "ba")?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Early word use shows language emergence.

tier1.question: Does your child understand familiar words like "no", "come", or "bye"?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Understanding words precedes speaking.

tier1.question: Does your child try to copy sounds you make?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Imitation supports speech development.

tier2.question: Does your child use at least 3-5 words consistently?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Word count indicates language progression.

tier2.question: Does your child follow simple one-step directions like "give me the toy" or "come here"?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Following directions shows understanding of language in context.

tier2.question: Does your child point to familiar objects or pictures when you name them?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Pointing to named items shows word-object association.

tier2.question: Does your child use different sounds or babble with varied intonation?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Varied vocalizations show developing speech patterns.

tier2.question: Does your child show you objects to get your attention or share interest?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Showing objects indicates social communication development.

tier1.question: Does your child make eye contact during interaction?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Eye contact supports shared attention.

tier1.question: Does your child smile or laugh in response to you or others?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Social smiling reflects engagement and connection.

tier1.question: When upset, does your child seek comfort from you or another caregiver?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Comfort-seeking is typical at this age.

tier1.question: Does your child show interest in faces or people nearby?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Interest in people supports social development.

tier1.question: Does your child enjoy games like peek-a-boo or pat-a-cake?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Interactive games show social engagement.

tier2.question: Does your child show affection to familiar people?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Affection indicates healthy attachment.

tier2.question: Does your child show stranger anxiety or cling to familiar adults in new situations?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Stranger anxiety is a normal sign of secure attachment at this age.

tier2.question: Does your child imitate your actions or gestures during play?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Imitation shows social learning and engagement.

tier2.question: Does your child show different emotions like happiness, sadness, or frustration?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Varied emotional expression shows developing emotional awareness.

tier2.question: Does your child respond to your emotions, like comforting you when you seem sad?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Early empathy shows social-emotional understanding.

domains.name: Cognitive / Learning
domains.description: Cognitive development involves thinking, problem-solving, memory, and understanding concepts. These skills form the foundation for academic learning and everyday decision-making. Strong cognitive abilities help children make sense of their world, learn new information, and apply knowledge in different contexts.

tier1.question: Does your child explore toys by shaking, banging, or mouthing them?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Exploration shows curiosity and learning.

tier1.question: Does your child look for a toy after seeing you hide it?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Object permanence is a key cognitive milestone.

tier1.question: Does your child repeat actions to make something happen again?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Understanding cause and effect supports problem-solving.

tier1.question: Does your child seem to recognize daily routines like feeding or bath time?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Routine recognition shows memory development.

tier1.question: Does your child use objects appropriately, like putting a phone to their ear or a cup to their mouth?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Functional play shows understanding of object purpose.

tier2.question: Can your child find a hidden object in a simple hiding game?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Finding hidden objects shows advanced cognitive skills.

tier2.question: Does your child try different ways to solve problems, like reaching a toy that's out of reach?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Problem-solving attempts show cognitive flexibility and planning.

tier2.question: Does your child explore how objects work, like pushing buttons or opening containers?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Exploratory behavior drives learning and discovery.

tier2.question: Can your child match similar objects or put shapes in corresponding holes?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Matching shows ability to recognize similarities and differences.

tier2.question: Does your child remember where frequently used objects are kept?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Object location memory shows developing spatial awareness.

domains.name: Adaptive & Self-Care
domains.description: Adaptive skills are practical life skills needed for independence, including dressing, eating, toileting, and personal hygiene. Mastering these skills builds confidence, reduces dependence on caregivers, and is essential for success in school and community settings. These abilities reflect a child's growing autonomy and self-management.

tier1.question: Does your child feed themselves finger foods?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Self-feeding is an important independence milestone.

tier1.question: Can your child drink from a cup with your help?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Cup drinking shows developing oral-motor control.

tier1.question: Does your child cooperate by holding out arms or legs when dressing?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Cooperation in dressing shows awareness and participation.

tier1.question: Does your child show interest when you wash hands, brush hair, or clean up?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Interest in self-care routines supports independence.

tier1.question: Does your child chew and swallow a variety of food textures?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Chewing variety shows oral-motor maturity and feeding skills.

tier2.question: Does your child attempt to use a spoon or fork?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Utensil use shows fine motor and self-care development.

tier2.question: Can your child drink from a cup independently without spilling much?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Independent drinking shows motor control and self-sufficiency.

tier2.question: Does your child try to remove simple clothing items like socks or a hat?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Removing clothes is an early self-care skill.

tier2.question: Does your child help with simple tasks like putting toys away when asked?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Helping with tasks shows understanding and cooperation.

tier2.question: Does your child indicate when their diaper is wet or soiled?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Awareness of elimination is a precursor to toilet training.

domains.name: Sensory Processing
domains.description: Sensory processing is how the brain receives and responds to information from the senses (touch, sound, sight, taste, smell, movement, body position). Difficulties in this area can affect attention, behavior, motor skills, and emotional regulation. Understanding a child's sensory needs helps create supportive environments for learning and development.

tier1.question: Does your child react strongly to loud sounds?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Helps identify sensory sensitivities.

tier1.question: Does your child avoid certain textures (food, clothing, surfaces)?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Texture avoidance may indicate sensory processing differences.

tier1.question: Does your child seek movement like rocking or bouncing?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Movement seeking can indicate sensory needs.

tier1.question: Does your child dislike grooming activities (hair brushing, nail cutting)?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Grooming resistance may indicate sensory sensitivities.

tier1.question: Does your child have difficulty calming after stimulation?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Calming ability reflects sensory regulation.

tier2.question: Does your child become overwhelmed in busy or noisy environments?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Environmental sensitivity indicates sensory processing patterns.

tier2.question: Does your child have strong preferences for or against certain food textures?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Food texture preferences reveal oral sensory processing patterns.

tier2.question: Does your child seem unusually sensitive or insensitive to pain or temperature?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Pain sensitivity variations may indicate sensory processing differences.

tier2.question: Does your child have difficulty tolerating being held or cuddled?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Touch tolerance affects bonding and physical comfort.

tier2.question: Does your child show extreme reactions to being wet, dirty, or messy?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Extreme reactions to mess may indicate tactile sensitivities.

domains.name: Vision & Hearing
domains.description: Vision and hearing are the primary channels through which children learn about their environment. Clear vision is essential for reading, writing, and visual-motor tasks, while good hearing is critical for language development and communication. Early detection of vision or hearing problems can prevent delays in other developmental areas.

tier1.question: Does your child respond to loud sounds?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Sound response indicates hearing function.

tier1.question: Does your child turn toward voices?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Turning to voices shows hearing and attention.

tier1.question: Does your child watch moving objects?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Tracking objects indicates visual development.

tier1.question: Does your child squint or bring objects very close to their face?
tier1.whyWeAsk: These behaviors may indicate vision problems.

tier1.question: Has your child had frequent ear infections?
tier1.whyWeAsk: Ear infections can affect hearing development.

tier2.question: Does your child make eye contact with you during play?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Eye contact during play shows visual and social connection.

tier2.question: Can your child recognize familiar people from across a room?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Recognizing people at a distance shows good visual acuity.

tier2.question: Does your child respond to soft sounds or whispers?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Response to quiet sounds indicates good hearing sensitivity.

tier2.question: Does your child notice small objects or details in pictures?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Noticing details shows fine visual discrimination.

tier2.question: Does your child respond differently to different types of music or sounds?
tier2.whyWeAsk: Sound discrimination shows refined auditory processing.
